trans-unit.source: Represents a Windows status bar control.
StatusStrip replaces the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar> control.

Special features of StatusStrip include a custom table layout, support for the form's sizing and moving grips, and support for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripStatusLabel.Spring%2A> property, which allows a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripStatusLabel> to fill available space automatically.

The following items are specifically designed to work seamlessly with both <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripSystemRenderer> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProfessionalRenderer> in all orientations.

They are available by default at design time for the StatusStrip control: - <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripStatusLabel> - <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripDropDownButton> - <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripSplitButton> - <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar> A StatusStrip control displays information about an object being viewed on a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form>, the object's components, or contextual information that relates to that object's operation within your application.
Typically, a StatusStrip control consists of <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripStatusLabel> objects, each of which displays text, an icon, or both.
The StatusStrip can also contain <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripDropDownButton>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripSplitButton>, and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripProgressBar> controls.
The default StatusStrip has no panels.

To add panels to a StatusStrip, use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripItemCollection.AddRange%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method, or use the [StatusStrip Items Collection Editor](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/7c56677b-d5eb-4eca-949c-a22c4e3833a1) at design time to add, remove, or reorder items and modify properties.
Use the [StatusStrip Tasks Dialog Box](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/c150678b-4873-4743-b23f-84fb3126582c) at design time to run common commands.

Although StatusStrip replaces and extends the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar> control of previous versions, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusBar> is retained for both backward compatibility and future use if you choose.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.StatusStrip"></xref> class.
Gets or sets a value indicating whether the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.StatusStrip"></xref> supports overflow functionality.

<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.StatusStrip"></xref> supports overflow functionality; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
The default is <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Creates a new accessibility object for the control.

If you do not explicitly call the CreateAccessibilityInstance method, it will be called when the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.AccessibilityObject%2A?displayProperty=fullName> property is referenced.

> [!NOTE] > To get or set the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.AccessibilityObject%2A?displayProperty=fullName> property, you must add a reference to the `Accessibility` assembly installed with the .NET Framework.
A new <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleObject"></xref> for the control.

Creates a default <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripStatusLabel"></xref> with the specified text, image, and event handler on a new <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.StatusStrip"></xref> instance.
Use the CreateDefaultItem method to add a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripStatusLabel> with commonly used characteristics to a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusStrip>.
The text to use for the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripStatusLabel"></xref>.
If the `text` parameter is a hyphen (-), this method creates a <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripSeparator"></xref>.
The <xref href="System.Drawing.Image"></xref> to display on the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripStatusLabel"></xref>.
An event handler that raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.Click"></xref> event when the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripStatusLabel"></xref> is clicked.
A <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripStatusLabel.%23ctor%28System.String%2CSystem.Drawing.Image%2CSystem.EventHandler%29?displayProperty=fullName>, or a if the text parameter is a hyphen (-).
Gets which borders of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.StatusStrip"></xref> are docked to the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripContainer"></xref>.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.DockStyle"></xref> values.
The default is <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.DockStyle"></xref>.
Gets the spacing, in pixels, between the left, right, top, and bottom edges of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.StatusStrip"></xref> from the edges of the form.
Use the DefaultPadding property to set the interior space between controls.
When a control is a container of items, padding represents the space from the edge of the container.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Padding"></xref> that represents the spacing.
The default is `{Left=6, Top=2, Right=0, Bottom=2}`.
Gets a value indicating whether ToolTips are shown for the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.StatusStrip"></xref> by default.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref> in all cases.
Gets the size, in pixels, of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.StatusStrip"></xref> when it is first created.
A <xref:System.Drawing.Point.%23ctor%2A> constructor representing the size of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.StatusStrip"></xref>, in pixels.
Releases the unmanaged resources used by the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.StatusStrip"></xref> and optionally releases the managed resources.
This method is called by the public `Dispose()`method and the <xref:System.Object.Finalize%2A> method.
`Dispose()` invokes the protected `Dispose(Boolean)` method with the `disposing` parameter set to `true`.
<xref:System.Object.Finalize%2A> invokes `Dispose` with `disposing` set to `false`.
When the `disposing` parameter is true, this method releases all resources held by any managed objects that this <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusStrip> references.
This method invokes the `Dispose()` method of each referenced object.

<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> to release both managed and unmanaged resources; <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref> to release only unmanaged resources.

Gets or sets which <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.StatusStrip"></xref> borders are docked to its parent control and determines how a <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.StatusStrip"></xref> is resized with its parent.
Use the Dock property to define how a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusStrip> is automatically resized as its parent control is resized.

For example, setting Dock to <xref:System.Windows.Forms.DockStyle> causes the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusStrip> to align itself with the left edges of its parent control and to resize as the parent control is resized.
Controls are docked in their Z-order, which is the visual layering of controls on a form along the form's Z-axis (depth).
A control can be docked to one edge of its parent container or can be docked to all edges and fill the parent container.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.DockStyle"></xref> values.
The default is <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.DockStyle"></xref>.
Gets or sets the visibility of the grip used to reposition the control.

Even with the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusStrip.SizingGrip%2A> property set to `true` and the GripStyle property set to `Visible`, the sizing grip will not be displayed unless you also set the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStrip.LayoutStyle%2A> property to one of the overflow values.

If the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStrip.LayoutStyle%2A> property is set to <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripLayoutStyle> or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripLayoutStyle>, the sizing grip will not be displayed.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripGripStyle"></xref> values.
The default is <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripGripStyle"></xref>.
Gets or sets a value indicating how the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.StatusStrip"></xref> lays out the items collection.
Use the LayoutStyle property to get or set how items are arranged on the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusStrip>.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripLayoutStyle"></xref> values.
The default is <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripLayoutStyle"></xref>.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.Layout"></xref> event.
The event data.
Paints the background of the control.
Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate.
For more information, see [Events](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
The OnPaintBackground method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate.
This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.PaintEventArgs"></xref> that contains information about the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.StatusStrip"></xref> to paint.
Provides custom table layout for a <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.StatusStrip"></xref>.
Override OnSpringTableLayoutCore to do custom table layouts.
The default value of <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripLayoutStyle> is <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripLayoutStyle>.
This property is not relevant for this class.
This property is not relevant for this class.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Padding"></xref> value.
This event is not relevant for this class.
This event is not relevant for this class.
To be added.
Resets the collection of displayed and overflow items after a layout is done.
Gets or sets a value indicating whether ToolTips are shown for the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.StatusStrip"></xref>.
Use the ShowItemToolTips property to get or set <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolTip> display behavior.

<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if ToolTips are shown for the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.StatusStrip"></xref>; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
The default is <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
Gets the boundaries of the sizing handle (grip) for a <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.StatusStrip"></xref>.
A <xref href="System.Drawing.Rectangle"></xref> representing the grip boundaries.
Gets or sets a value indicating whether a sizing handle (grip) is displayed in the lower-right corner of the control.
You can use the SizingGrip property to display a grip to provide an indication to the user of when a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusStrip> is resizable.

Even with the SizingGrip property set to `true` and the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.StatusStrip.GripStyle%2A> property set to `Visible`, the sizing grip will not be displayed unless you also set the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStrip.LayoutStyle%2A> property to one of the overflow values.

If the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStrip.LayoutStyle%2A> property is set to <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripLayoutStyle> or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripLayoutStyle>, the sizing grip will not be displayed.
<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if a grip is displayed; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
The default is <xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref>.
Gets or sets a value indicating whether the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.StatusStrip"></xref> stretches from end to end in its container.

<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.StatusStrip"></xref> stretches from end to end in its <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripContainer"></xref>; otherwise, <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
The default is <xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref>.
Processes Windows messages.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Message> structure wraps messages that Windows sends.
You can use this structure to wrap a message and assign it to the window procedure to be dispatched.
You can also use this structure to get information about a message the system sends to your application or controls.
You cannot create the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Message> structure directly.
To create a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Message> structure, use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Message.Create%2A> method.

To make creating <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Message> structures more efficient, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Message> structure uses its pool of existing <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Message> structures instead of creating an instance of a new one, if possible.
However, if a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Message> structure is not available in the pool, a new instance of the structure is created.
The Windows <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Message"></xref> to process.
